(2013) Alignment-Free Sequence Comparison Based on Next-Generation Sequencing Reads. J Comp. Biol, 20, 64–79. Liu, X. M., Wan, L., Li, J., Gesine R., Michael S. Waterman., Sun, F. Z. (2011) New powerful statistics for alignment-free sequence comparison under a pattern transfer model. J. Theor. Biol, 284(1), 106-116. ***

- Li C. Xia: email: lcxia@scut.edu.cn

- Xuemei Liu: email: liuxm@scut.edu.cn

- Ziqi Cheng: email: php@mail.scut.edu.cn

Phylogenetic analysis is the cornerstone of evolutionary biology and taxonomy. Phylogeny based on molecular sequence similarity has become the de facto standard. All subsequences of size k derived from a molecular sequence are called its k-mers. Numerous studies demonstrated that k-mers of molecular sequences, such as genomic DNA and proteins are conserved within closely related organisms, and diverge with speciation. Thus k-mer statistics are efficient and effective phylogenetic distance measures. As shown in the Fig. 1, we developed Ksak - a tool that not only efficiently computes seven widely accepted k-mer statistics: Chebyshev (Ch), Manhattan (Ma), Euclidian (Eu), Hao, d2, d2S and d2star, but also performs alignment-free phylogenetic analysis. By applying it to the golden standard 16S rRNA dataset, we extensively benchmarked the accuracy and efficiency of Ksak by comparing to other popular phylogenetic analysis tools：Muscle, ClustalW2, Mafft and Cafe. We made the software of Ksak open source. Ksak runs on MS Windows operating systems with a graphical user interface. ![image](images/0.png)
Fig. 1 (a) The computation framework of Ksak; (b) Accuracy benchmark results; (c) Efficiency benchmark results; (d) An example phylogeny tree output of Ksak.
***

Phylogenetic analysis is the cornerstone of evolutionary biology and taxonomy. Phylogeny based on molecular sequence similarity has become the de facto standard. All subsequences of size k derived from a molecular sequence are called its k-mers. Numerous studies demonstrated that k-mers of molecular sequences, such as genomic DNA and proteins are conserved within closely related organisms, and diverge with speciation. Thus k-mer statistics are efficient and effective phylogenetic distance measures. 
As shown in the Fig. 1, we developed Ksak - a tool that not only efficiently computes seven widely accepted k-mer statistics: Chebyshev (Ch), Manhattan (Ma), Euclidian (Eu), Hao, d2, d2S and d2star, but also performs alignment-free phylogenetic analysis. By applying it to the golden standard 16S rRNA dataset, we extensively benchmarked the accuracy and efficiency of Ksak by comparing to other popular phylogenetic analysis tools：Muscle, ClustalW2, Mafft and Cafe. We made the software of Ksak open source. Ksak runs on MS Windows operating systems with a graphical user interface.

result.original_header: 3. How to use ***Ksak.exe*** to analyze the example data?
result.value: ### 2. Where can I get the example data? We have provided some example fasta formatted data in the directory [data], you can get the input sequence data in [sequences] and the outgroup data in the directory [outgroup]. Use these data as template to construct your own data.

result.original_header: 2. Where can I get the example data?
result.value:
② Click Add button in Input panel, then pick the sequences in [data/sequences] (Hold Shift key to multi-select); ③ Click Inputs/Add Outgroup in the main menu, then pick the sequences in [data/outgroup]; ## 1. The user interface of Ksak
Fig. 2 The user interface of Ksak is shown below.
As shown in the Fig. 2, the red area is the main menu, where you can set the language, graphic font and other options. The yellow area is the input sequences, where you can view and edit the sequences with highlight colors. The green area is the configuration panel, where you can configure the options of clustering and plotting algorithm, etc. The blue area is the output panel, where you can view and export the generated trees. The purple area is the status bar, where the current progress of calculation and plotting is displayed. This panel is used to configure the calculation parameters. In the Distance multiple selector you can configure the distance algorithm which is needed for the calculation. In the k-string length field you can configure the interval information for k-string length. In the Markov model field you can configure the interval information for Markov model. In the Tree Constrcution Method field you can configure the clustering algorithm (Unweighted pair-group method with arithmetic means (UPGMA) or Neighbor Joining (NJ)). After the calculation is complete, the obtained tree is presented on the Output panel. We can select to review different styles of output trees (Standard and Circular). Meanwhile, by right clicking on the output display area you can choose Save or Save All ... to save the results to bmp image, tree description file or distance matrix. Double-click the output display area, outputs can be reviewed separately in a pop-up box. ## 2. Advanced features of Ksak Ksak has multi-window view: Multiple windows can be opened for easy comparison from tree to tree; Ksak allows users to produce plots, mark colors, and set fonts with one click; Ksak supports Chinese & English languages. In addition, right click on the sequence name in the shortcut menu, you can mark the sequence with selected color. In this way, the sequences are color-categorized before comparison, and the output evolution tree is very clear. The output of Ksak can be saved in three ways. The first way is in image form, and you can output all the plots from all parameters at once and save them in a folder. The second way is in matrix form, where all the plots from all parameters are saved in matrix form, stored in the same folder. The third way is to save in the notepad form, where all sequences are output in the format with parameter description. These three ways are shown in Fig. 8. For the output results saved in the form of evolution trees, Ksak can switch the output in 7 presentation forms as shown in Fig. 9-15 below, this allows one to visualize the different clustering effects of species as needed. Huang, G. D., Liu, X. M., Huang, T. L., Li C. Xia. (2019) The statistical power of k-mer based aggregative statistics for alignment-free detection of horizontal gene transfer. Synthetic and Systems Biotechnology, 4(3), 150--156. [link](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2405805X19300304)
Ksak: A High-throughput Tool for Alignment-free Phylogenetics

- Li C. Xia: email: lcxia@scut.edu.cn

- Xuemei Liu: email: liuxm@scut.edu.cn

- Ziqi Cheng: email: php@mail.scut.edu.cn

# Ksak: A High-throughput Tool for Alignment-free Phylogenetics # README ## Introduction Phylogenetic analysis is the cornerstone of evolutionary biology and taxonomy. Phylogeny based on molecular sequence similarity has become the de facto standard. All subsequences of size k derived from a molecular sequence are called its k-mers. Numerous studies demonstrated that k-mers of molecular sequences, such as genomic DNA and proteins are conserved within closely related organisms, and diverge with speciation. Thus k-mer statistics are efficient and effective phylogenetic distance measures. As shown in the Fig. 1, we developed Ksak - a tool that not only efficiently computes seven widely accepted k-mer statistics: Chebyshev (Ch), Manhattan (Ma), Euclidian (Eu), Hao, d2, d2S and d2star, but also performs alignment-free phylogenetic analysis. By applying it to the golden standard 16S rRNA dataset, we extensively benchmarked the accuracy and efficiency of Ksak by comparing to other popular phylogenetic analysis tools：Muscle, ClustalW2, Mafft and Cafe. We made the software of Ksak open source. Ksak runs on MS Windows operating systems with a graphical user interface. ![image](images/0.png)
Fig. 1 (a) The computation framework of Ksak; (b) Accuracy benchmark results; (c) Efficiency benchmark results; (d) An example phylogeny tree output of Ksak.
*** ## Install ### 1. Where can I get Ksak? You need to clone or download this project, then locate to [bin/Release]. After double-clicking Ksak.exe, you'll see the program graphical interface immediately.

result.original_header: 2. Where can I get the example data?
result.value:
We have provided some example fasta formatted data in the directory [data], you can get the input sequence data in [sequences] and the outgroup data in the directory [outgroup]. Use these data as template to construct your own data. ### 3. How to use Ksak.exe to analyze the example data? ① Double-click to run Ksak.exe in [bin/Release]; ② Click Add button in Input panel, then pick the sequences in [data/sequences] (Hold Shift key to multi-select); ③ Click Inputs/Add Outgroup in the main menu, then pick the sequences in [data/outgroup]; ④ Check Eu (or some other measures if you like) in the Configuraion panel, and modify the K-mer length and Markov Background Order (optional), then click the Run button; ⑤ The results will appeared in the Output panel. *** ## Manual (Windows) ## 1. The user interface of Ksak ![image](images/image1.png)
Fig. 2 The user interface of Ksak is shown below.
### 1.1. Main menu As shown in the Fig. 2, the red area is the main menu, where you can set the language, graphic font and other options. The yellow area is the input sequences, where you can view and edit the sequences with highlight colors. The green area is the configuration panel, where you can configure the options of clustering and plotting algorithm, etc. The blue area is the output panel, where you can view and export the generated trees. The purple area is the status bar, where the current progress of calculation and plotting is displayed. ### 1.2. Configuration panel This panel is used to configure the calculation parameters. In the Distance multiple selector you can configure the distance algorithm which is needed for the calculation. In the k-string length field you can configure the interval information for k-string length. In the Markov model field you can configure the interval information for Markov model. In the Tree Constrcution Method field you can configure the clustering algorithm (Unweighted pair-group method with arithmetic means (UPGMA) or Neighbor Joining (NJ)). ### 1.3. Status bar After importing and configuring the input sequences, you can click the Generate button to start running the software. The running progress can be viewed in this area. ### 1.4. Output panel After the calculation is complete, the obtained tree is presented on the Output panel. We can select to review different styles of output trees (Standard and Circular). Meanwhile, by right clicking on the output display area you can choose Save or Save All ... to save the results to bmp image, tree description file or distance matrix. Double-click the output display area, outputs can be reviewed separately in a pop-up box. In the example run, we input the comparison sequences in the Iutput sequences and run Ksak and obtain the output evolutionary tree directly. ![image2](images/image2.png)
Fig. 3 An example run of Ksak.
## 2. Advanced features of Ksak Ksak has multi-window view: Multiple windows can be opened for easy comparison from tree to tree; Ksak allows users to produce plots, mark colors, and set fonts with one click; Ksak supports Chinese & English languages. Ksak's graphical interface is roughly divided into three panels. The left column is used to input sequences. One can clear the input sequence by clicking the Clear button. Import the sequence file by opening the input dialog box as shown in the figure by clicking the Add button. As shown in the Fig. 4, meanwhile, the Input box supports file/folder drag-and-drop operation and will automatically apply the fasta format file in the folder to import. Double-click the sequence file name you can review the sequence information. ![image3](images/image3.png)
Fig. 4 Import sequences to Ksak.
  In addition, right click on the sequence name in the shortcut menu, you can mark the sequence with selected color. In this way, the sequences are color-categorized before comparison, and the output evolution tree is very clear. ![image4](images/image4.png)
Fig. 5 Set sequence color in Ksak.
  Ksak can output two types of clustering tree, including UPGMA clustering and NJ clustering. The following figures (Fig. 6-7) show their example outputs. ![image5](images/image5.png)
Fig. 6 UPGMA clustering
  ![image6](images/image6.png)
Fig. 7 NJ clustering
  The output of Ksak can be saved in three ways. The first way is in image form, and you can output all the plots from all parameters at once and save them in a folder. The second way is in matrix form, where all the plots from all parameters are saved in matrix form, stored in the same folder. The third way is to save in the notepad form, where all sequences are output in the format with parameter description. These three ways are shown in Fig. 8. ![image7](images/image7.png)
Fig. 8 Three output formats of Ksak.
  For the output results saved in the form of evolution trees, Ksak can switch the output in 7 presentation forms as shown in Fig. 9-15 below, this allows one to visualize the different clustering effects of species as needed. ![image8](images/1.png)
Fig. 9 Standard form.
  ![image9](images/2.png)
Fig. 10 Circular form.
  ![image10](images/3.png)
Fig. 11 Align text form.
  ![image11](images/4.png)
Fig. 12 Triangular form.
  ![image12](images/5.png)
Fig. 13 Bezier form.
  ![image13](images/6.png)
Fig. 14 Circular triangular form.
  ![image14](images/7.png)
Fig. 15 Circular bezier form.
## References: X. M. Liu, Z Cheng, G Xu, J Xie, X Liu, B Ren, D Ai, Y Chen, Li C. Xia (2023) Ksak: A high-throughput tool for alignment-free phylogenetics. Frontiers in Microbiology, 14, 1050130. [link](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10098151/) Huang, G. D., Liu, X. M., Huang, T. L., Li C. Xia. (2019) The statistical power of k-mer based aggregative statistics for alignment-free detection of horizontal gene transfer. Synthetic and Systems Biotechnology, 4(3), 150--156. [link](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2405805X19300304) Song, K., Ren, J., Zhai, Z. Y., Liu, X. M., Deng, M. H., Sun, F. Z. (2013) Alignment-Free Sequence Comparison Based on Next-Generation Sequencing Reads. J Comp. Biol, 20, 64–79. Liu, X. M., Wan, L., Li, J., Gesine R., Michael S. Waterman., Sun, F. Z. (2011) New powerful statistics for alignment-free sequence comparison under a pattern transfer model. J. Theor. Biol, 284(1), 106-116. *** # Contact & Support: - Li C. Xia: email: lcxia@scut.edu.cn - Xuemei Liu: email: liuxm@scut.edu.cn - Ziqi Cheng: email: php@mail.scut.edu.cn

result.original_header: 3. How to use ***Ksak.exe*** to analyze the example data?
result.value:
# Ksak: A High-throughput Tool for Alignment-free Phylogenetics # README ## Introduction Phylogenetic analysis is the cornerstone of evolutionary biology and taxonomy. Phylogeny based on molecular sequence similarity has become the de facto standard. All subsequences of size k derived from a molecular sequence are called its k-mers. Numerous studies demonstrated that k-mers of molecular sequences, such as genomic DNA and proteins are conserved within closely related organisms, and diverge with speciation. Thus k-mer statistics are efficient and effective phylogenetic distance measures. As shown in the Fig. 1, we developed Ksak - a tool that not only efficiently computes seven widely accepted k-mer statistics: Chebyshev (Ch), Manhattan (Ma), Euclidian (Eu), Hao, d2, d2S and d2star, but also performs alignment-free phylogenetic analysis. By applying it to the golden standard 16S rRNA dataset, we extensively benchmarked the accuracy and efficiency of Ksak by comparing to other popular phylogenetic analysis tools：Muscle, ClustalW2, Mafft and Cafe. We made the software of Ksak open source. Ksak runs on MS Windows operating systems with a graphical user interface. ![image](images/0.png)
Fig. 1 (a) The computation framework of Ksak; (b) Accuracy benchmark results; (c) Efficiency benchmark results; (d) An example phylogeny tree output of Ksak.
*** ## Install ### 1. Where can I get Ksak? You need to clone or download this project, then locate to [bin/Release]. After double-clicking Ksak.exe, you'll see the program graphical interface immediately. ### 2. Where can I get the example data? We have provided some example fasta formatted data in the directory [data], you can get the input sequence data in [sequences] and the outgroup data in the directory [outgroup]. Use these data as template to construct your own data. ### 3. How to use Ksak.exe to analyze the example data? ① Double-click to run Ksak.exe in [bin/Release]; ② Click Add button in Input panel, then pick the sequences in [data/sequences] (Hold Shift key to multi-select); ③ Click Inputs/Add Outgroup in the main menu, then pick the sequences in [data/outgroup]; ④ Check Eu (or some other measures if you like) in the Configuraion panel, and modify the K-mer length and Markov Background Order (optional), then click the Run button; ⑤ The results will appeared in the Output panel. ***
